description:
This PR fixes a bug which occurs if you try to use the annotate_halos callback wherein it fails because the kwargs were set as None instead of empty dictionaries.

It fixes a bug/typo in the thin_slice_projection recipe.

Lastly, it adds a cookbook recipe demonstrating how to use rockstar on a nested cosmology simulation where one has multiple particle mass data.  I am actually using it on the sample dataset Enzo_64, which is *not* a nested sim, but it works for that as well.  I put this information together from the discussions we had on the yt-users mailing list a couple of weeks ago.  

Unfortunately, I don't think this recipe will actually *work* under the current cookbook system because it requires mpi to be run with >3 processors so that rockstar can run OK.  So @xarthisius may want to disable this from being run on the doc-generating server.  That said, I've had requests offline for this script, which is why I thought I'd post it, as it is non-trivial to do on one's own.

UPDATE1: removing empty dictionaries from default argument values to avoid iterative errors.

UPDATE2: Assuring the script be run using mpirun >=3 procs thanks to @samskillman and @xarthisius 's suggestions.  Modifying the print statement to use the python3 method for designating strings thanks to @ngoldbaum 's solution.
title: A couple of bug fixes and a new cookbook recipe for running rockstar on nested cosmo runs

pullrequest.title: A couple of bug fixes and a new cookbook recipe for running rockstar on nested cosmo runs

content.raw: @chummels we can't use mutables like dicts in function signatures. The idiom is for them to be None, and inside the body of the function, checking if they are None and if so setting them to {}.
content.html: Cameron Hummels we can't use mutables like dicts in function signatures. The idiom is for them to be None, and inside the body of the function, checking if they are None and if so setting them to {}.

pullrequest.title: A couple of bug fixes and a new cookbook recipe for running rockstar on nested cosmo runs

content.raw: Weird.  It seems to run OK even now that I've set the arg to be {} by default.  I can just as well change it to be None and then have a check for it, but as it was wouldn't work and as it is works.  Is it just a convention or will it actually fail in certain circumstances?
content.html: Weird. It seems to run OK even now that I've set the arg to be {} by default. I can just as well change it to be None and then have a check for it, but as it was wouldn't work and as it is works. Is it just a convention or will it actually fail in certain circumstances?

pullrequest.title: A couple of bug fixes and a new cookbook recipe for running rockstar on nested cosmo runs

content.raw:
The objects are only created at function declaration, so any changes will
be reflected in subsequent calls. I don't have my standard example script
handy, but this is a convention we enforce throughout yt. Most if not all
of the callbacks use this for the arguments passed on to matplotlib, as do
the field parameters, etc.
content.html: The objects are only created at function declaration, so any changes will be reflected in subsequent calls. I don't have my standard example script handy, but this is a convention we enforce throughout yt. Most if not all of the callbacks use this for the arguments passed on to matplotlib, as do the field parameters, etc.

pullrequest.title: A couple of bug fixes and a new cookbook recipe for running rockstar on nested cosmo runs

content.raw: Prior to this modification, all annotation quantities were output as floats.  So for instance if you specify the halo_ids, you get out: "0.0 dimensionless, 1.0 dimensionless, N.0 dimensionless", whereas if you specify halo mass you get: "123456789012.1234, 1234567891012.1234", etc.  By switching to "%g" it removes the "dimensionless" and plots floats for small numbers and then scientific notation for large numbers.  I tried to do this within the new format for print statements, ie. '{0:g}'.format(dat.value), but it gave me errors about dat.value being a string even though it was a 0-d array of a float.  I spent 15 minutes trying to make this work and then gave up because '%g' worked without any problems.
content.html: Prior to this modification, all annotation quantities were output as floats. So for instance if you specify the halo_ids, you get out: "0.0 dimensionless, 1.0 dimensionless, N.0 dimensionless", whereas if you specify halo mass you get: "123456789012.1234, 1234567891012.1234", etc. By switching to "%g" it removes the "dimensionless" and plots floats for small numbers and then scientific notation for large numbers. I tried to do this within the new format for print statements, ie. '{0:g}'.format(dat.value), but it gave me errors about dat.value being a string even though it was a 0-d array of a float. I spent 15 minutes trying to make this work and then gave up because '%g' worked without any problems.

pullrequest.title: A couple of bug fixes and a new cookbook recipe for running rockstar on nested cosmo runs

content.raw: `'{:g}'.format(float(dat))` should work, I think.
content.html: '{:g}'.format(float(dat)) should work, I think.

pullrequest.title: A couple of bug fixes and a new cookbook recipe for running rockstar on nested cosmo runs

content.raw: pep8 says no spaces around `=` for keyword arguments.  While I don't think you should fix all the cases where that happens in this file, you shouldn't add any new ones in a pull request.
content.html: pep8 says no spaces around = for keyword arguments. While I don't think you should fix all the cases where that happens in this file, you shouldn't add any new ones in a pull request.
